There are $m$ possible numbers for a ballot ($7 \le m \le 10^9$). 7 parties will be assigned one of these numbers each, with no repeats.  

A party wants to know how many ways the numbers can be assigned so that the number assigned to the party in question has more lucky digits (4 or 7) than the sum of lucky digits in the numbers assigned to the other 6 parties.

Output the number of valid assignments modulo $10^9 + 7$.

You are given a set of numbers. 7 groups need to be assigned one number each from this set, with no repeats.  Two numbers are considered "lucky".  How many ways can you assign the numbers so that the lucky number count for one specific group is strictly higher than the total lucky number count for the other 6 groups?
